ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to work on a large-scale project with multiple people working on discrete chunks. I also got my first taste on designing and programming a robot to accomplish a task (in this case, moving around an obstacle from point A to B).
I learned how to solder and engineer. That means designing something and have it work until the 8th iteration.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One big weakness of this course is the lack of ability to choose the project on the part of the students. I realize that past projects were poorly defined and unsuccessful, so perhaps the administration felt some pressure to ensure the success of this year's, however I think the execution was a bit ham-handed. It would be great to allow groups to plan their own projects. Depending on ABET requirements, it would be good to get this planning started in the Fall, and have students get together early to discuss. If students can define their own roles and goals, I think they will take on more interesting projects, take on more responsibilities, and have better results.

The biggest weakness is that I couldn't pick my own project. I'm more on the theoretical side and my assigned section of the project was mostly hands-on and played to none of my strengths or research areas. I made the most of what was given to me but I wish I could have chosen my own project

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: While this course has its own flaws, I will take this opportunity to express some criticism of the major as a whole, since this is the climactic senior project. I think the EE dept needs a bit of a shakedown and needs to improve before I can wholeheartedly recommend the ABET EE track (and thus this course) to anyone. For faculty: take a look at other prominent organizations' pedagogy. MIT, for instance, has awesome, practical labs and instruction. There is much that can be done to make courses in the EE major better. More coding projects and practical, hands-on use of real industry tools could be incorporated throughout. EE majors need to know good coding practice (beyond ENAS130) too! Hindsight is 20-20 and probably gives me a more critical perspective, but I feel that there are a good number of holes in the Yale EENG curriculum that could be filled, especially given the weight that the name of Yale is supposed to convey. This does not mean I haven't had my share of sleepless nights, and that more work should be piled on. It's simple: the EE dept courses need to be looked at and systematically restructured and optimized to better prepare students for the industry.
If you aren't ABET, find a professor and a project that best suit your interests. You'll have a much more rewarding experience.
